sub_topic: Determining the volume of a cone.
message_1: A conical tank has a radius of 5 meters and a height of 10 meters. What is the volume of water (in cubic meters) that the tank can hold when it is filled up to its brim?
message_2:
To find the volume of a cone, we use the formula:

Volume = (1/3)πr²h

where r is the radius, h is the height, and π (pi) is approximately 3.14159.

In this case, the radius (r) is 5 meters and the height (h) is 10 meters. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

Volume = (1/3)π(5)²(10)

Volume = (1/3)π(25)(10)

Volume = (1/3)π(250)

Volume ≈ (1/3)(3.14159)(250)

Volume ≈ 261.7994 cubic meters

So, the conical tank can hold approximately 261.8 cubic meters of water when filled up to its brim.
